review.title: Evolutionary Search in the Space of Rules for Creation of New Two-Player Board Games
review.abstract: Games have always been a popular test bed for artificial intelligence techniques. Game developers are always in constant search for techniques that can automatically create computer games minimizing the developer's task. In this work we present an evolutionary strategy based solution towards the automatic generation of two player board games. To guide the evolutionary process towards games, which are entertaining, we propose a set of metrics. These metrics are based upon different theories of entertainment in computer games. This work also compares the entertainment value of the evolved games with the existing popular board based games. Further to verify the entertainment value of the evolved games with the entertainment value of the human user a human user survey is conducted. In addition to the user survey we check the learnability of the evolved games using an artificial neural network based controller. The proposed metrics and the evolutionary process can be employed for generating new and entertaining board games, provided an initial search space is given to the evolutionary algorithm.

sections.heading: 2.9 Structure of the chromosome
sections.text: 1. The chromosome consists of a total of 50 genes. The first 24 genes can contain values from 0 to 6, with 1 representing a piece of type 1, 2 representing a piece of type 2, and so on. Zero is not interpreted as a piece. The figure type represented by gene 1 is placed in cell 1 of the game board; piece type represented by gene 2 is placed in cell 2 of the game board, and so on. Gen 25 to 30 represents motion logic for each character type, with 1 for diagonal forward and backward, 2 for diagonal forward and diagonal, 3 for all directions, 4 for L-shaped motion, 5 for straight and backward, and 6 for straight. Genes 31 to 36 are used for step size of each type, where 0 is used for single step size and 1 for multiple step size. Genes 37 to 42 are used for step size of each type, where 0 is used for step of each type, with 0 being used for step of the step of the game, and 1 for step of the step of the game.

sections.heading: 3. Fitness Function and Evolutionary Algorithm
sections.text: Evolutionary algorithms need a mechanism to evaluate the fitness of individuals in the population. Our goal is to develop new games that are entertaining to play. Therefore, the fitness function must have properties that can somehow quantify the entertainment value of a game. In fact, we are looking for an answer to the question: "What are the factors that make one board game more interesting than another?" To answer this question, a look at the psychology literature might be helpful. Some theories that are of interest are described in the following paragraphs.

sections.heading: 4. Software Agents for Playing the Games
sections.text: Since the evolutionary algorithm develops a population of games and the fitness of each game must be determined in each generation, we can have several thousand such fitness evaluations in total. Fitness evaluation means playing the game several times, which is not possible manually. We need software game agents. The smarter the agent, the better the accuracy of the fitness evaluation. We have developed two types of such agents: Random Agents. Agents that use Min-Max with rules-based evaluation function.

sections.heading: 4.1. Random Agent
sections.text: The agent follows the following algorithm listed in Fig. 3: The agent first generates all legal moves and stores them in a queue; the queue is shuffled as soon as all moves are stored in it; shuffling is important because we need an average of 20 games to calculate the individual metrics; if the queue is not shuffled, the same sequence of moves is used to play the game every time the game is played, and fitness values remain the same in each sequence of games; if the duty to capture the bit is "turned on" in a chromosome that is being evaluated, the agent first tries to find a move that captures the opponent's figure; if no such move is found, he randomly selects a move from the queue.

sections.heading: 4.2. Agent using Min-Max with rule based evaluation function
sections.text: Intelligent Agent generates all possible single-layer boards with a minimum max. algorithm. Each resulting board is evaluated on the basis of a rules-based evaluation function and the board with the highest evaluation depth is selected as the next move. Evaluation function allocates priorities (weights) to the type of piece, depending on whether its disappearance would result in the end of the game, the flexibility of movement and the capture of logic. Once the priority of a board is calculated, we multiply each board by its corresponding weight and calculate the weighted sum for ourselves and the opponent. The board evaluation is the self-weighted sum minus the weighted sum of the opponents. Fig. 4 lists the algorithm for the evaluation function we use. Since we use min-max of a single-layer sequence, we had to integrate a mechanism into the evaluation function to use the random effect minus the weighted sum of the opponents minus the weighted sum of the weighted sum of the evaluation function.

sections.heading: 5.1. Evolution of New Games
sections.text: To create new and entertaining board games, we use 1 + 1 EvolutionaryStrategy (ES). First, a population of 10 chromosomes is randomly initialized with permissible values, and the evolutionary algorithm is executed for 100 iterations. Mutation is the only genetic operator that is used with a mutation probability of 30 percent. In each iteration of the ES, one parent generates a child and a fitness difference is calculated between them. If this is greater than 4 (i.e. the child is at least half better than its parent), it is moved to the next population. We use the formula given in Equation (6) to calculate the fitness difference.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: The idea of evolving the game rules to produce new and entertaining games is intriguing.In this thesis we have introduced the automatic search for entertaining and new board games. To this end, we first define a search space that is extracted using the popular board and checkers games. This search space is provided to the evolutionary algorithm in the form of the chromosome population.To direct the evolutionary algorithm towards entertaining games, we propose a series of metrics that are extracted on the basis of different entertainment theories. The metrics include game duration, the intelligence required for the game, the dynamics exhibited by the game pieces, and the ease of use of the game.The results of our evolutionary search in the area of rules for creating new board games for two players 23 experiments are verified on the basis of the entertainment value of the human user, by conducting a human user survey, and an experiment on the learning type of the game, which may be more interesting than the entertainment function developed by controllers (the idea of using the entertainment function).
